lg.l: The Rod was but a harmless Wand,
While Moses held it in his Hand,
But soon as e'er he laid it down,
'Twas a devouring Serpent grown.
Our great Magician Hamet Sid,
Reverses what ye Prophet did;
His Rod was honest English Wood,
That senceless in a Corner stood,
Till Metamorphos'd by his Grasp,
It grew an all-devouring Asp,
Would hiss, & sting, & roll, & Twist,
By ye meer Virtue of his Fist:
But when he laid it down, as quick
Resum'd ye Figure of a Stick.
So to Her Midnight Feasts ye Hag,
Rides on a Broomstick for a Nag,
That, rais'd by Magick of her Breech,
O'er Sea & Land convys ye Witch;
But with ye Morning-Dawn resumes
The Peacefull State of Comon Brooms.
They tell us something strange & odd,
About a certain Magick Rod,
That, bending down it's Top, divines
When e'er ye Soil has Golden Mines:
Where there are none, it stands erect,
Scorning to show ye least Respect.
As ready was ye Wand of Sid
To bend where Golden Mines were hid;
In Scottish Hills found precious Ore,
Where none e'er look'd for it before;
And by a gentle Bow, divin'd
How well a Cully's Purse was lin'd:
To a forlorn & broken Rake,
Stood wtḥout Motion like a Stake.
The Rod of Hermes was renown'd
For Charmes above & under Ground;
To sleep could Mortal Eye-lids fix
And drive departed Souls to Styx.
That Rod was Iust a Type of Sid's,
Which o're a British Senate's Lids,
Could scatter Opium full as well,
And drive as many Souls to Hell.
Sid's Rod was Slender, White & Tall,
Which oft he us'd to fish withall
A Place was fastned to ye Hook,
And many score of Gudgeons took;
Yet still so happy was his Fate,
He caught his Fish & sav'd his Bait.
Sid's Brethren of ye Conj'ring Tribe
A Circle wth their Rod describe,
Which proves a Magical Redoubt
To keep mischievous Spirits out:
Sid's Rod was of a larger Stride
And made a Circle thrice as wide,
Where Spirits throng'd wtḥ hideous Din,
And he stood there to take them in.
But when ye enchanted Rod was broke,
The vanish'd in a stinking Smoak.
Achilles's Scepter was of Wood,
Like Sid's, but nothing near so Good,
Tho' down from Ancestors Divine
Trnsmitted to ye Heroes Line,
Thence thro' a long Descent of Kings,
Came an Heir-loom, as Homer sings,
Tho' this Description looks so big,
That Scepter was a sapless Twig:
Which from ye fatall Day when first
It left ye Forest where 'twas Nurst,
As Homer tells us us o'er & o'er,
Nor Leaf, nor Fruit, nor Blossom bore.
Sid's Scepter, full of Iuice, did shoot
In Golden Boughs, & Golden Fruit,
And He, ye Dragon never sleeping,
Guarded each fair Hesperian Pippin.
No Hobby-Horse, wtḥ gorgeous Top,
The dearest in Charles Mather's Shop,
Or glitt'ring Tinsell of May-Fair,
Could wtḥ this Rod of Sid compare.
Dread Sr, then why wer't thou so mad
To break thy Rod like naughty Lad?
You should have kist it in yoṛ Distress,
And then return'd it to yoṛ Mistress,
Or made it a Newmarket Switch,
And not a Rod for thy own Breech.
For since old Sid has broken this,
His next will be a Rod in Piss.132-904A
